string-array.name: aurora_excerpts
string-array.item: Northern lights, or aurora borealis, are dancing streaks of light that can appear as curtains, waves, and spirals.
Northern lights are caused by activity on the surface of the Sun, which produces electrically charged particles that interact with the magnetic field of Earth.
The best place to see Northern Lights is the auroral zone, an area within a fifteen hundred mile radius of the North pole.
Green is the most common color for northern lights, and blue and red are the rarest. The different colors are due to different types of gas particles.

string-array.name: sunhalo_excerpts
string-array.item: A sun halo is a circle of light that forms around the sun or moon.
Sun halos are caused by cirrus clouds, which contain tiny ice crystals. The reflection of light from those crystals creates the halo.
The cirrus clouds that cause sun halos occur at high altitudes of over 20,000 feet.
Different crystal shapes can make different types of sun halos. Sun pillars, for example, are caused by hexagonal ice crystals.

string-array.name: biobay_excerpts
string-array.item: The wonder of "bioluminescent shores" occurs when the sea sparkles a neon blue or green, or even red.
Bioluminescence is light emitted by living organisms, such as algae; in the ocean, this produces a stunning effect.
The most famous bioluminescent shore is the Mosquito Bay in Puerto Rico. However, this phenomenon occurs at many other locations.
While bioluminescence can be beautiful, it could also signify danger. For example, many bioluminescent dinoflagellates are considered toxic.
